item.title: ОS2. External course. Part 1
item.description:
The first section of the course “Linux System Administrator from scratch” is presented here.

Objective

Complete the first section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

Task

Tasks from the first, second, and third modules, as well as tests.

Theoretical Introduction

  • Module 1: Introduction to System Administration
  • Module 2: Basic Linux Commands
  • Module 3: Files and Directories

Practical Tasks Execution

Installing the htop utility.

Running htop and sorting processes by RAM usage.

Finding out how much free disk space is left.

Finding the subdirectories occupying the most space in the /var directory.

Reading the latest kernel-related messages from the system journal.

Checking the SSH status.

Getting a list of all active services.

Finding the configuration file for the SSH service. Opening it with a text editor, such as nano, and reviewing the settings specified there.

Viewing which logs are present in the system.

Viewing the last twenty entries in the system journal.

Finding out if “third-party” applications not managed by the package manager are used in the system.

Imagining that the Nginx web server is installed in the system and we need to reconfigure it. Going to the configuration directory, finding the file with the main settings, making a backup copy before changes, opening the file for editing, and restarting the service after changes.

Getting information about the processor.

Requesting data on memory usage. Paying attention to the fields: MemTotal, MemFree, Buffers, and others.

Viewing the list of files in the /dev directory.

Finding out the current directory. Moving to the home directory and getting a list of all files, including hidden ones. Viewing the last ten entries in the syslog system journal related to the systemd service.

Creating a ‘project’ directory, and inside it creating several subdirectories: logs, data, and backup.

Creating text files: error.log in the ~/project/logs/ directory and info.txt in the ~/project/data/ directory. Then verifying that the files have been created.

Copying the info.txt file from the ~/project/data directory to the ~/project/backup folder.

Moving the error.log file from the ~/project/logs/ directory to the ~/project/data/ folder.

Deleting the project folder along with all its contents.

Creating an archive_test.tar.gz archive using tar and gzip methods, placing three files inside it: file1.txt, file2.txt, file3.txt.

Extracting the archive_test.tar.gz archive into the ~/extracted directory.

Transferring the archive_test.tar.gz archive from the local computer to the server in the backups folder. Using the IP address 192.168.1.10 and the username ‘user’.

Creating a clean_logs.sh script that will archive all logs in the /var/log directory.

Making the script executable and running it.

Automating the script execution using cron. Configuring the clean_logs.sh script to run on the first day of each month at 3:30 AM.

Test Tasks Execution

Because the freedom defining free software is the freedom to study, modify, and improve the program.

Zabbix, as it is a specialized, powerful, and widely used monitoring system.

The key task of a system administrator is to ensure the stability and availability of the IT infrastructure.

Bash is the most common and standard command shell in most Linux distributions.

Man, when we need to get the most complete and structured reference information about a command, utility, or system call.

We elevate privileges when we need to perform an action affecting the entire system or other users.

We forgo the graphical interface on servers because it allows us to direct all computational resources to performing core service tasks, rather than rendering graphics.

We use SSH because this protocol provides us with an encrypted network connection for secure remote server management.

We distinguish these concepts as follows: A Terminal is a program that provides us with a text interface for entering commands and viewing results. A Shell is a command interpreter that runs inside the terminal, reads the commands we enter, executes them, and returns the result.

We know that the /etc directory is the standard location for storing global configuration files for the system and installed programs.

We refer to the /var/log directory because it is specifically intended for storing constantly growing files, which include logs.

We use the /opt directory to install third-party proprietary software or large software packages that come as self-contained builds and are not managed by the distribution’s package manager.

We view the /dev directory as a virtual filesystem where the Linux kernel represents all physical and virtual devices as special files.

We use the /proc virtual filesystem as a window into the system kernel.

We use the cat command to view the contents of virtual files in /proc and /dev because it works with any files, simply outputting their contents to the standard output.

We use the pwd command to precisely determine which directory we are currently in. This is a basic command for navigation and orientation in the filesystem. We use the -a flag with the ls command to display all files, including hidden ones whose names start with a dot. We use a relative path. Since we are already in the /etc directory, to navigate to its apache2 subdirectory, the command cd apache2 is sufficient.

We use the tilde symbol (~) as a shortcut that the shell automatically expands to the absolute path of the current user’s home directory. We build such a pipeline when we need to filter the detailed output of the ls -l command and keep only those lines containing the substring “ssh”.

We use the tar command with the -c, -z, and -f keys to create a compressed tarball archive from the specified folder. We use the tar command with the -x, -z, and -f keys to unpack a compressed tarball archive. We use the scp command with the -r key to securely copy an entire folder along with its contents via SSH to a remote server.

We use the chmod command with the +x key to give the current user the right to run the file as a program or script. We use the # symbol in Bash scripts and many other scripting languages to denote the start of a comment. We use this find command to search the /var/log directory for files modified more than 7 days ago and for each found file, execute the command to force its deletion.

Test Scores

Conclusions

We have completed the first section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

References

::: {.refs}

  1. https://study.selectel.ru/members/courses/course756726784647 :::

item.title: ОS2. External course. Part 2
item.description:
The second section of the course “Linux System Administrator from scratch” is presented here.

Objective

Complete the second section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

Task

Tasks from the fourth, fifth, sixth, and seventh modules, as well as tests.

Theoretical Introduction

  • Module 4: Getting Help. Using reference systems, working with text files and logs
  • Module 5: User and Group Management
  • Module 6: Access Control
  • Module 7: Process Management

Practical Tasks Execution

Using man to learn how the grep command works.

Finding documentation about systemctl using info.

Opening the local documentation about info.

Opening the /etc/os-release file using less and finding the distribution name.

Using grep to find lines containing “error” in the /var/log/syslog file.

Editing the SSH configuration using nano or vim and changing the PermitRootLogin parameter to no.

Creating a small file with a matrix of numbers of arbitrary size, and experimenting with the numbers using the awk utility — for example, calculating the sum of numbers in each even row.

Finding all errors in the system log from the last day.

Checking SSH logs and finding failed login attempts.

Writing a script that daily saves all errors from /var/log/syslog to a file.

Configuring cron so the script runs once a day.

Using grep to count the number of failed login attempts in the last 24 hours.

Creating a new user ‘ivan’ and setting a password for them.

Creating a new group ‘developers’. Adding user ‘ivan’ to the ‘developers’ group. Creating a group ’testers’ and changing user ‘ivan’s group membership from ‘developers’ to ’testers’. Deleting the user account ‘ivan’ along with their home directory.

Creating a new file somewhere. Examining the permissions it received automatically. They have these specific values because of umask.

For the created file, removing write permissions for the group and read permissions for others. Restoring the original permissions to the file using the numeric form.

Making the root user the owner of the file.

Taking back ownership of the file.

Performing several actions using sudo and finding them in the system log.

Using the ‘ivan’ account from previous lessons. Checking if they can execute superuser commands. If not, granting them this ability.

Displaying the names of all users who have the outdated SHA-512 algorithm specified for their password hashing (its prefix is $6$).

Creating user ‘ivan’. Setting the required password policy parameters for them using the chage command. Locking the ‘ivan’ user account.

Verifying that they cannot log into the system.

Restoring the ‘ivan’ user’s ability to log in.

Checking the access permissions for /etc/passwd, /home, and /var/log.

Creating a file in the home directory, checking its permissions, and setting umask so that new files have no permissions for the ‘others’ category.

Creating a file and setting its permissions to 644, so the owner can edit, and others can only read. Creating an ‘admins’ group, changing the group of the file created in the first task to this one, and granting the group write permission.

Allowing a specific user to modify the file without adding them to the owner’s primary group. Setting special permissions for the group so they can only execute the file. Checking and resetting all ACLs on the file.

Setting the SUID on an executable file so it runs with the owner’s privileges. Configuring SGID for a directory so new files inherit the group. Making it so the ‘others’ category can write to /public_folder but cannot delete others’ files.

Finding the process consuming the most memory and terminating it.

Starting a process in the background, bringing it to the foreground, suspending the process, then returning it to the background.

Installing and running htop, configuring the desired columns, finding a process by filter and “killing” it.

Starting a task with low priority — for example, with nice=15. Finding the PID of a previously started process and increasing its priority to -5. Finding the process with the lowest priority and trying to increase its priority.

Listing all active services and filtering them by the “Network” filter. Determining which web server is installed, checking the service status, and restarting it. After restarting, checking the log for errors.

Finding an unnecessary service. Ensuring that this process does not start upon system reboot. Rebooting the device and checking that the selected service is turned off.

Creating a simple Python script and giving this file execution rights.

Creating a unit file — activating and checking the status of your unit.

Forcibly terminating the process that was started in the previous task and checking the service status.

Rebooting the device and checking if the autostart of your process worked.

Test Tasks Execution

When we need to get a complete and structured description of a utility, its options, and usage examples, we refer to the built-in manual using the man command. We use the info command as an alternative to man for viewing more detailed documentation. We know that after installing a package, its additional documentation, licenses, and configuration examples are usually placed in the /usr/share/doc/package_name directory.

We use the cat > file.txt construct to redirect standard input into a new file. We use the >> operator when we need to append data to the end of an existing file without erasing its previous content. The > operator always creates a file anew or completely overwrites an existing one. For viewing large files, we prefer to use less because it allows us to scroll through content page by page, search text, and move freely through the file, whereas cat dumps all content at once, which is inconvenient for navigation.

To exit the less viewer, we simply press the q key. In the Vim editor, while in Normal mode, we press the : key to switch to Command mode.

We refer to the /var/log/ directory as it is the standard location for storing system and application logs. We use this command to filter and view all systemd journal entries related to the sshd service since the start of the current day. To see a limited number of recent entries, we use the -n key. The command journalctl -n 20 will output the last 20 lines of the journal.

To monitor a growing log file in real time, we use the tail command with the -f flag. We know that individual cron jobs for each user are stored as files in the /var/spool/cron/ directory.

In a cron entry, we use the asterisk symbol * to denote “every” valid value in a field (e.g., every minute, every hour). To completely clear our personal cron table, we run the crontab -r command.

When creating a user, we use the -m flag so the system automatically creates a default home directory for them. To completely remove a user account along with their home directory and all its contents, we use the userdel command with the -r flag.

We use this command to grant the ‘admin’ user superuser privileges. The -aG flag ensures the user is added to the sudo group without losing other group memberships. For editing critical system files /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow, we use the special vipw utility. It locks the file during editing, preventing simultaneous modification from elsewhere, which ensures data integrity.

The first character in the ls -l output indicates the file type. The letter ’d’ means it is a directory. We use the chown command in the format “chown owner:group file” to simultaneously change the owner and group of a file. We decode the numeric permission format as follows: 7 (owner: rwx), 5 (group: r-x), 4 (others: r–). This corresponds to the string rwxr-xr--.

All commands executed via sudo are logged in the system journal, allowing us to track who, when, and what was done with root privileges. After changing the SSH port, the daemon will run on the new port, but the firewall by default blocks all incoming connections except those allowed by rules.

To allow incoming connections to a non-standard SSH port, we add a rule to UFW explicitly specifying the port number and protocol: sudo ufw allow 47022/tcp. We prefer sudo because it allows granting privileged access without disclosing the root password, provides detailed logging of actions, and offers more flexible rights management through the /etc/sudoers file.

We understand that hashing is a one-way cryptographic function. The hashing algorithm identifier, such as $6$ (SHA-512) or $y$ (yescrypt), tells the system which method was used to generate that hash. We add a “salt” — a random string — to the password before hashing. This ensures that even identical passwords will have different hashes.

To check password policy settings, we use the chage command with the -l flag. The usermod -L command locks a user account by prepending a ! to the beginning of their hashed password in /etc/shadow, making it impossible to log in with that password.

To view a detailed list of files, including their access permissions, owner, and group, we use the ls -l command. The combination of -l and -a flags in the ls command allows us to see the permissions of all files, including hidden ones. We convert symbolic permissions to numeric: r (read) = 4, w (write) = 2, - (no execute) = 0. Sum: 4 + 2 + 0 = 6.

To change access permissions, we use the chmod command. In the symbolic mode of the chmod command, we use operators: + to add permissions, - to remove permissions, and = to set permissions to an exact value. To recursively apply permission changes to all files and subdirectories within a directory, we use the -R flag.

We set the Sticky Bit on public directories like /tmp so users can only delete their own files, even if they have write permission to the directory. SUID is a special permission that causes an executable file to run with the privileges of its owner, not the user who launched it. Such a parameter does not exist.

To get a detailed list of all processes in the system with information about the user, PID, CPU, and memory usage, we use the ps aux command. When a process does not respond to other signals, we use the kill -9 command, which sends the SIGKILL signal. We suspend a process running in the terminal by pressing Ctrl+Z. Then, to resume its execution in the background, we enter the bg %1 command.

The nice value determines the scheduler’s priority. The lower the value, the higher the process priority. Thus, a value of -20 is the highest priority, and 19 is the lowest. To change the priority of an already running process, we use the renice command. In a systemd unit file, we use the Nice= directive to set the nice value for all processes of this service upon their startup.

To check the state, activity, and recent logs of a system service, we use the systemctl status service_name command. In a systemd timer, we use the OnCalendar= directive with the daily parameter to schedule a daily run at midnight. To have a service start automatically at system boot, we “enable” it using the systemctl enable command. This creates the necessary symbolic links.

We use the Restart=always directive in a systemd unit file when we need the service to automatically restart regardless of how it ended — normally, with an error, or was forcibly stopped. This ensures maximum service fault tolerance. To monitor the log of a specific service in real time, we use the journalctl -u servicename -f command. Before running a new service, we always check its unit file for syntax errors using the systemd-analyze verify command.

Test Scores

Conclusions

We have completed the second section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

References

::: {.refs}

  1. https://study.selectel.ru/members/courses/course756726784647 :::

item.title: ОS2. External course. Part 3
item.description:
The third section of the course “Linux System Administrator from scratch” is presented here.

Objective

Complete the third section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

Task

Tasks from the eighth, ninth, tenth, and eleventh modules, as well as tests.

Theoretical Introduction

  • Module 8: Network and SSH Configuration
  • Module 9: Package Management
  • Module 10: Log Management
  • Module 11: Containerization with Podman

Practical Tasks Execution

Configuring a static IP on the test server manually.

Writing the configuration for the eth0 interface in the /etc/network/interfaces file.

Checking the accessibility of external resources via ping.

Removing the current IP address from the interface. Starting any web server on port 80 (e.g., nginx) and checking that it works.

Using the dig utility to find out the IP addresses of popular services.

Checking if the SSH port is listening on the server.

Changing the SSH port and disabling password login.

Configuring key-based connection and authorizing.

Allowing SSH access only for specific users. Verifying that connection for another user does not work.

Configuring UFW to restrict access only to SSH.

Configuring UFW so that SSH access is only allowed from your local network.

Using fail2ban, creating a jail that will block an IP address after three successful requests to nginx.

Checking how the blocking works with multiple requests.

Finding and installing the htop utility.

Removing the htop utility, then reinstalling it with complete purge.

Performing a full system update.

Configuring automatic installation of security updates.

Removing obsolete and unused dependencies.

Installing a package manually via dpkg, after downloading it from the website.

Analyzing which dependencies will be required.

Viewing the contents of the main system log and authentication log using a paging utility.

Displaying the last 20 entries from the binary system log using journalctl.

Checking the existence and location of the Nginx web server error log file.

Studying any one line from the /var/log/auth.log file and manually identifying: the timestamp, service (process) name, and event description.

Checking the current status of the rsyslog and systemd-journald services using systemctl.

Generating a test message using the logger utility. Then finding this message first in the journalctl output, and then in the /var/log/syslog file. Using journalctl, filtering and displaying only events with error (err) severity level or more critical. Looking into the rsyslog configuration file (e.g., /etc/rsyslog.d/50-default.conf) and finding the line responsible for directing messages from the auth and authpriv facilities to the /var/log/auth.log file. Sending a message with an explicitly specified warning severity level to the system log. Verifying that it appears in the journalctl output when filtered by this level.

Finding all lines in the /var/log/auth.log file that mention a failed password login attempt (Failed password), ignoring case. Building a command pipeline that first finds all successful SSH connections (Accepted password) in /var/log/auth.log, and then extracts only the IP addresses of the connected clients from these lines. Compiling a list of unique IP addresses from which failed login attempts were recorded. Collecting statistics and displaying the five IP addresses from which the largest number of successful SSH logins were recorded.

Using journalctl, displaying all system logs from the last 15 minutes.

Finding all login attempts by non-existent users in the authentication log /var/log/auth.log.

Determining the IP address from which the largest number of failed password attempts (Failed password) were made. After identifying the most suspicious IP address from the previous step, extracting absolutely all entries related to this IP from /var/log/auth.log and saving them in a separate file incident_report.log. Calculating the SHA256 checksum for the created incident_report.log file to record its integrity and prove that it has not been modified after collection. Checking which commands were executed with superuser privileges (via sudo) by your current user.

Studying the existing logrotate configuration for the system package manager (apt or dpkg) in the /etc/logrotate.d/ directory. Determining how often rotation occurs, how many archival copies are stored, and whether compression is used.

Creating a custom configuration file /etc/logrotate.d/testapp to manage a fictional log file /var/log/testapp.log. Configuring it for daily rotation, storing four archival copies, and compressing old logs.

Checking the created logrotate configuration for syntax errors by performing a “dry run” in debug mode.

Forcing rotation for the testapp log and checking the result: ensuring that the old log was compressed and renamed, and a new empty file appeared in its place. Writing a configuration line for rsyslog that will forward absolutely all logs (.) via TCP protocol to a remote server with the address logs.example.com and the standard port 514.

Installing Podman and verifying the installation.

Starting a container.

Starting Nginx and verifying that it works.

Deploying a website in Nginx using a local folder with HTML files.

Running an Nginx container with memory limited to 100 MB and checking its operation.

Investigating the container’s behavior when the allocated memory is exhausted.

Creating and running a custom website based on nginx using Podman.

Saving the image and transferring it to another server.

Test Tasks Execution

We use the ip a add command to temporarily add an IP address to a network interface. The auto directive in the /etc/network/interfaces file tells the system which interfaces to automatically activate (bring up) during boot. To remove a specific IP address from an interface, we use the ip a del command specifying the full address with mask and the interface name.

Settings configured using the ip command are temporary and only last until system reboot. When statically configuring the network in the /etc/network/interfaces file, we specify the default gateway using the gateway directive in the interface configuration block.

We use the modern ss utility with the -t, -u, -l, -n, -p keys to get a complete list of open ports and the processes associated with them. The -p key in the ss command forces it to display the Process ID (PID) and name of the process using the socket.

We use the dig command to perform DNS queries and get detailed information about domain names, including their IP addresses. For quickly checking the availability of a remote TCP port, we use the netcat utility with the -v and -z keys.

By default, the SSH server daemon listens for incoming connections on TCP port 22. The main configuration file for the SSH server is located at /etc/ssh/sshd_config. The ssh_config file is for the client side. To temporarily stop a system service, we use the systemctl stop command.

To set up SSH key authentication, we copy the contents of the public key file to the authorized_keys file on the server. The PermitRootLogin no directive in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file prohibits direct SSH connection to the server under the root account, which is an important security measure.

After configuring the rules, we activate the UFW firewall with the ufw enable command. This applies the rules and enables firewall autostart at system boot. The main Fail2ban jails settings, which define blocking rules, are stored in the /etc/fail2ban/jail.conf file. To remove a rule by its number from the list displayed by the ufw status numbered command, we use the ufw delete [number] command.

The bantime parameter in the Fail2ban jail configuration defines the duration of IP address blocking in seconds after exceeding the attempt limit. To restrict access to a port by source, we use the syntax ufw allow from [source] to any port [port]. This allows connections only from the specified subnet.

The apt autoremove command removes packages that were automatically installed as dependencies and are no longer needed. The target packages themselves are removed with the remove command, and their configs remain. The apt purge command removes a package along with its configuration files. Dependencies installed with it remain in the system. We regularly run apt update to update the local package database. Without this, the system will not know about new package versions.

The unattended-upgrades package allows us to configure automatic installation of security updates and other packages without manual intervention. After apt update, we run apt upgrade to install all available updates for installed packages. The apt full-upgrade command performs a smarter update that may remove obsolete packages or install new dependencies, which is sometimes necessary for a full system update.

When dependency problems occur, we use the apt --fix-broken install command to try to automatically fix broken dependencies. Forcibly removing a package on which other programs depend leads to “dependency breakage”. To filter the output of other commands and search for a specific package, we use a pipeline with grep.

We prefer to install .deb files via apt, as it automatically resolves and installs all dependencies. APT checks the integrity and authenticity of packages from repositories using GPG keys, which protects the system from installing modified or malicious packages. In a corporate environment, if the required package is not in the approved repositories, the correct action is to request its addition through the ticketing system, not to install it yourself from unverified sources.

We use logs primarily for these three purposes: to find the cause of a malfunction, to investigate the circumstances of a hack, and to identify “bottlenecks” in the system. Error 502 usually indicates a communication problem between the web server and the backend process. In modern systems, logs are stored in two main places: classic text files in /var/log/ and the centralized systemd binary journal, which we view using journalctl.

Typically, systemd-journald acts as the primary log collector, and then, if settings are present, forwards messages to the syslog daemon for permanent storage in familiar text files in /var/log/. The failure to start a critical system service is a significant negative event classified as an error level, not just an informational message. A facility in syslog indicates the subsystem or program that is the source of the message.

For uniq to correctly count duplicate lines, they must follow each other. In awk, $1, $2, $3, etc. denote the first, second, third, and subsequent fields in a line. We use a pipeline: the first grep filters lines with “error”, and the second grep with the -v key removes lines containing “healthcheck” from this result.

A large number of failed login attempts in a short period of time, especially for standard usernames, is a classic sign of an automated brute-force attack. Calculating the hash records the current state of the file. Commands executed via sudo are extensively logged in authentication logs.

The main task of logrotate is the rotation, archiving, and deletion of old log files according to a set schedule and rules. Remote log collection ensures log integrity. Grafana Loki is designed specifically for this scenario.

The podman info command outputs detailed information about the Podman environment: version, configuration, storage, network, etc., which helps us verify its correct setup. The key architectural difference of Podman is that it uses a daemonless architecture. The --rm key automatically removes the container immediately after it finishes its work.

Podman’s security for multi-user environments is due to its ability to operate in rootless mode. As already noted, Podman does not require a constantly running background daemon.

We use the podman run command to start a new container. The -v flag is used to mount directories or files from the host machine into the container. The combination of the -i and -t flags allows us to run the container in interactive mode with a pseudo-TTY.

By default, podman ps shows only running containers. To see all containers, including stopped ones, we add the -a flag. The --rm flag forces Podman to automatically remove the container immediately after it is stopped.

To monitor the resource consumption of running containers in real time, we use the podman stats command. The -d flag runs the container in the background. After launch, control returns to the terminal, and the container continues to run independently. After modifying systemd unit files, we run systemctl daemon-reload.

When a container is run as a systemd service, its logs are integrated into the general systemd journal. The --memory flag sets the maximum limit of RAM that the container can use.

To download Docker images from a remote registry, we use the podman pull command. The policy.json file defines the trust policy for container images. In it, we configure which registries are allowed to download images from, whether a digital signature is required for them, and which keys are trusted. The podman build command is used to build your own container image.

We use podman build -t myapp . to create our own image from the instructions in the Dockerfile located in the current directory. The result will be an image named myapp. If the trust policy (policy.json) for a specific registry or image specifies the signedBy directive, then Podman will check for the presence and validity of a digital signature for the image.

Test Scores

Conclusions

We have completed the third section of the external course “Linux System Administrator from Scratch”.

References

::: {.refs}

  1. https://study.selectel.ru/members/courses/course756726784647 :::
